# Control Panel Display Settings

## Display Settings Overview

| Display Character | Description                          | Set Value |
|-------------------|--------------------------------------|-----------|
| COOL              | Cooling mode                         | -         |
| CYCL              | Cyclic mode                          | -         |
| t1                | Cool Time                            | 180       |
| t2                | Cyclic ON Time                       | 3         |
| t3                | Cyclic OFF Time                      | 55        |
| t4                | Fault reset time in minutes         | 3         |
| t5                | R2 ON time in seconds                | 5         |
| SP                | Temperature Set Point                | -9        |
| Can               | No of Cans                          | 4 / 6     |
| EXIT              | EXIT                                 | -         |
| FLT               | HP/LP Fault cap reached              | -         |
| RST               | Reset                                | -         |
| HPLP              | HP/LP fault                          | -         |

### Instructions
1. Follow the same procedure for t2, t3, t4, t5, and SP.
2. Set all values as mentioned in the control panel setting table.
3. Come to the last checkpoint of Can selection and select 4 or 6 Can system according to the milk availability.
- For 4 Can, the compressor is off during chilling time (t1).
- In 6 can condition, the compressor runs during chilling time.
4. Now EXIT will be displayed on your screen. Press SET to exit the programming mode.

----

## 2.1 Micro Can Chiller Start Procedure
a) Turn on power supply.
b) OFF will be displayed in the beginning if SWITCH is off.
c) COOL will be displayed on the display first after turning on the Switch.
d) Hold SET button and enter the programming mode.
e) Once SET is displayed, t1 will come on screen.
f) Press SET button to enter t1 and now using UP and DOWN buttons set the desired value for t1. After that, again press SET button to exit that.

### Note
- After Cooling Mode, Cyclic Mode will turn ON automatically.

----

## 2.2 MODE
- **When SWITCH is:**
- a) OFF: Operation is off
- b) ON: Cooling Mode (Discharge pump is ON for t1 time)

# Innovative Cooling Solutions

## Micro Can Chiller Troubleshooting

### Micro Can Chiller Troubleshooting: Common Problems

Even when regularly inspected and maintained, the performance of your system may degrade or deteriorate over time. Pumps can fail; process lines can clog; refrigerant can leak; any number of problems associated with component aging or changing environmental conditions may occur (Table I and Table II). Here are some initial steps to take to help isolate the problem:

1. **Make sure that the chiller is running.** Loose wiring, or simply a power switch that’s been put in the ‘off’ position may be preventing the chiller from running.

2. **Determine if the chiller is cooling.** Check the temperature of the coolant at the chiller’s outlet to the process. If it isn’t at or near the set point temperature, the evaporator may be iced up or the heat transfer properties of the coolant fluid may be deteriorating.

3. **Confirm that the pump is running.** A closed or partially closed valve, failed pump, inadequate coolant/Brine volume, or process line restriction may be preventing the adequate flow of liquid through the ice bank coolant loop.

4. **Check the process and environmental conditions.** Likewise, a change in the location of the chiller (near other heat generating equipment); loose, damaged, or missing insulation on the piping between the chiller or even fluctuations in line voltage may be compromising the chiller’s heat removal capabilities.

### Common Micro Can Chiller Faults

All Micro Can chillers display a fault or error code when conditions affecting performance are detected. These codes are usually specific and will help you quickly diagnose problems. Some of the more common alarms and faults are:

- **HP LP Fault**

- **High Discharge Pressure Alarm**
The refrigerant discharge pressure is too high. This may be due to a dirty or blocked condenser, dirty air filter, failing cooling fan, high ambient temperature, or over-charging of the refrigerant system.

- **Low Discharge Pressure Alarm**
The refrigerant discharge pressure is too low. This may be caused by refrigerant leakage, clogging of the condenser tubing, under-charging of the refrigerant system, or low ambient temperatures.

Regular preventative maintenance and knowing what to look for when the performance of your chiller deteriorates will help you optimize the uptime of both your chiller and the process it is cooling.

## Innovative Cooling Solution

### 1.0 USER’S RESPONSIBILITY

The basic rules of safety set forth in this section are intended as a guide for the safe operation of Promethean Spenta Technologies Conventional Milk Chiller (CMC). This general safety information, along with explicit service, maintenance, and operational materials for each specific model, make up the complete instruction manual.

All personnel who will operate or service or be involved with this equipment in any way should become totally familiar with this information prior to start-up. It is the Buyer’s responsibility to make certain that these procedures are followed and, should any major deviation or change in use from the original specifications be required, appropriate procedures should be established for the continued safe operation of the machine.

It is strongly recommended to contact Promethean Spenta Technologies to make certain the machine can be converted to the new use in a reasonably safe manner. If the machine is not purchased directly from Promethean Spenta Technologies or its representative, it is the responsibility of the purchaser to ensure that the machine complies with the valid safety regulations. It is strongly recommended that the purchaser contacts Promethean Spenta Technologies to safeguard that the machine can be operated in a reasonably safe manner.

# 2.0 INTRODUCTION

This manual provides the information necessary to operate and maintain the 1000 liters Conventional Milk Chiller (CMC). The system is manufactured and designed to chill 1000 liters of milk per day, i.e., 50% of rated capacity in the morning & 50% in the evening.

The Conventional Milk Chiller (CMC) chills the milk from 35°C to 4°C within 03 (Three) hours. The CMC system mainly comprises the following modules which are assembled at the factory; interconnections of modules are made at the site during installation.

1. **Condensing Unit**
2. **Thermal Storage System (TSS)**
3. **Active Milk Cooling & Storage Tank**
4. **Control Panel**

## 2.1 CONDENSING UNIT

The condensing unit has the following main salient features:

- The Compressor is of Emerson make Scroll type and is suitable for charging the TSS within the specified time when grid power is available. The model presently used is ZB 21 KQE PFJ 524.
- Generously sized Air Cooled Condenser with a condenser fan of 20” sweep for condenser cooling.
- High Pressure / Low Pressure switch with safety device.
- The refrigeration system works with environmentally friendly R-404a refrigerant.
- Accumulator of suitable size & capacity.
- Liquid line Filter Drier, Sight Glass.
- Thermostatic Expansion Valve with suitable Orifice.
- Brazed type Plate Heat Exchanger forms the evaporator.
- Control Panel comprising necessary electrical fittings of suitable rating.
- Base Frame with MS Structure to accommodate all above in a compact manner.

## 2.2 THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM

The Thermal Storage System (TSS) is the heart of the system which stores the Thermal Energy during the availability of grid power and releases the same for chilling milk when required. This is normally referred to as a battery too. The TSS unit comprises the following:

- TSS Tank made of high-grade LLDPE (Linear Low Density Polyethylene) material and insulated with PUF to prevent loss of stored Thermal Energy.
- High-performance Magnetic AC Pump for Coolant circulation.
- PCM Tubes.
- Black Gate Hose, Diffuser, Valves with Strainer, etc.

## 2.3 ACTIVE MILK STORAGE TANK

**Construction:** Horizontal, Semi-Cylindrical Open type Milk Tank fabricated out of AISI 304 material for both inner and outer shell in sanitary design with high density (40 Kg/Cu. M) injected PUF insulation. The tank will be provided with a single piece detachable un-insulated lid at the top. The tank is provided with adjustable ball feet.

**Scope of supply includes:**
- Energy-efficient coolant circulation jacket made of stainless steel plates pressed and formed by spot welding, which forms the bottom of the tank.

# RMC Control and Installation Manual

## 2.4 CONTROL PANEL

The Control Panel comprises necessary electrical fittings of suitable rating to control and monitor the entire operation of the RMC. This controller is based on Battery Temperature, Milk Temperature, and Auxiliary Temperature. It has the following main features:

### A. Power Supply
- **Voltage**: 24VDC

### B. Analog Inputs
- Battery Temperature Sensor
- Milk Temperature Sensor
- Auxiliary Sensor

### C. Digital Inputs
- HP input
- LP input
- Power fail
- Over Voltage / Under Voltage
- Compressor under load / over load
- Pump under load / over load
- Battery Low / High
- Inverter fail

### D. Digital Outputs
- Compressor
- Condenser
- Pump
- Agitator
- Inverter
- Shiva
- Valve
- Pump 2
- Alarm

### E. User Interface
- The user interface has a **16 x 2 LCD** with a blue backlight, a 3-digit seven-segment display, LEDs to indicate the status of outputs and faults, and 5 keys to navigate between different screens to view the status of the unit, change set points, and reset alarms.
- The LCD displays various information such as:
- AC Voltage
- AC Current of Compressor and Pump
- Battery Voltage
- Compressor run hours
- Open/close status of Shiva
- Inverter Status
- In program mode, it shows values and descriptions of parameters.
- The seven-segment display indicates the Battery Temperature, Milk Temperature, and Auxiliary Temperature depending on the selection.
- LEDs show the current status of equipment like Compressor, Pump, and all fault statuses.
- The controller has 5 keys: **PRG, UP, DOWN, SET, and RESET**. These keys are used in normal mode to navigate different screens and in program mode to change various parameter values.

## 3.0 INSTALLATION

- Ensure that the flooring is complete and strong enough to support the gross weight of the tank, including the product at full capacity.
- Install the tank on leveled ground and ensure proper leveling of the tank.
- Maintain enough space around the condensing unit so that each component can be easily accessed for repair and maintenance.
- Proper ventilation around the air-cooled condenser is crucial for the refrigeration system to operate without issues. The condenser should continuously breathe fresh atmospheric air.
- The condensing unit fan should suck air freely and deliver hot air to the surroundings without any obstruction between the condensing unit. There should be no obstruction in the inlet and outlet air passages.

# Installation and Setup Guidelines

## 1. General Requirements

- The wall should have a window for delivering hot air outside the room.
- **Window Size:** 1400 x 1400 mm
- **Height from Floor:** 350 mm
- Ensure that the condensing unit is not exposed to:
- Dust
- Direct sunlight
- Any other heat-emitting gadgets
- Provide a grill door or shutter for the main door with an opening for good ventilation.
- About **250 liters** of good quality RO Water (look for ISI mark) to be provided for the first charging of the TSS.

## 2. Electrical Requirements

- Use **4.0 sq. mm, 3-core armored insulated Copper cable** for incoming supply.
- The distance between the supply point and the electric control panel should be a maximum of **5 meters**. If the distance is more, select a higher size cable to compensate for the voltage drop.
- Connect earthing (minimum two numbers) at connector “E” in the electric control panel.
- The voltage at the MAINS ON switch should be within the limit.
- Ensure minimum distance between Milk outlet from SHIVA & inlet to Silo. The distance should not exceed **500 mm**.

## 3. Equipment Setup

### 3.1 Chiller Unit

- Place the Chiller Unit such that the condenser fan faces the window for expelling hot air outside.
- Mount the Control Panel on the MS Structure.
- Ensure that the Panel is easily accessible to the operator.
- Fix the AC Pump base frame on the MS Structure and install the Pump on it.
- Place the DC Battery and Inverter in the Frame and install them.

### 3.2 Preparation of TSS

- Clean the TSS Tank properly and position it nearer to the CU.
- Fix all diffuser lines in respective SS pipe ends inside the TSS.
- Connect all the **¾” Ball Valves** at:
- Hot Discharge
- Cold Suction
- Cold Discharge Line
- Ensure all connections are leak-proof.
- Connect the Ball Valve at the TSS on the Hot Suction Line and ensure it is leak-proof.
- Connect all interconnecting lines:
- Hot Suction Line
- AC Pump Suction Line
- AC Pump Discharge Line
- PHE Inlet
- PHE Outlet
- Cold Discharge Line
- Insulate properly with Aeroflex.
- Fill **230 liters** of RO water and add **110 liters** of IPA to it. Stir for about **30-40 minutes** to ensure proper mixing.
- Run the Coolant circulation pump for proper mixing of IPA with Water.
- Put the PCM tubes inside the TSS, ensuring they float vertically. After placing all tubes, fix the wire mesh over them in the TSS. Ensure that no PCM tubes come above the mesh.
- Top up RO Water in the TSS to maintain the required level.
- Run the AC Pump for at least **2-3 hours** to ensure proper mixing of IPA & RO Water.

### 3.3 Active Milk Storage Tank

- Install the AC Pump on the base frame provided.
- Fix a **¾” Ball Valve** at the Inlet of the Pump.
- Connect the Pipe Lines between:
- CMC & TSS Cold Suction
- AC Pump Suction
- AC Pump Discharge
- Tank Inlet
- Tank Outlet
- Hot Discharge at TSS
- Ensure all joints are leak-proof.
- Insulate these lines with insulation tubes.
- Ensure that the Vertex Breaker is placed in the Hooper.
- Ensure the Hot & Cold lines are connected at the appropriate terminals.

### 3.4 Control Panel

- Install the Control Panel on the frame at the Chiller Unit MS Structure.
- Connect the Sensor wires (all three) to the Control Panel and place the Sensor Tip at the respective locations.
- Connect the DC Supply line from the DC Battery to the Panel Board and complete all internal wirings.

# Operation and Maintenance Manual

## 4.0 Starting the Unit

Before starting the unit, check the following:

1. Main supply with specified Voltage and earthing is provided.
2. All parameters in the Control Panel are set to factory values.
3. Lid of the electric control panel is closed and locked.
4. Valve in the Charging Line is opened.
5. Switch ON the Power ON MCB; this will energize the Control Panel. After a preset delay period, the Charging Pump will start, and coolant from TSS will start circulating to PHE & back to TSS.
6. Switch ON the Chiller Unit MCB. This will start the compressor and condenser fan.
7. Note down the Battery Temperature, Discharge Pressure, Suction Pressure, and Current drawn by the compressor.
8. The CU will automatically stop when the Battery Temperature reaches its preset temperature. Check that the PCM Tubes are frozen properly.
9. Now the CMC is ready for milking.
10. Fill the Tank with at least 250 liters of water/milk.
11. Switch ON the TANK Switch; the discharge pump will start, and Battery Fluid will start flowing to the Tank. The agitator will start.
12. Continue until the temperature of the milk reaches 4°C.
13. Keep the TANK switch ON until there is milk in the Tank so that the Discharge Pump will automatically start as the milk temperature goes above the set point.
14. During milking, the battery temperature will raise slowly, and when it reaches the preset point, the CU will start automatically.
15. Never turn OFF the Power MCB.

## 5.0 Cleaning of Milk Tank

After the milk is dispatched, the tank must be carefully cleaned:

- A lukewarm water pre-rinse will wash away the majority of fat deposits.
- The best pre-rinse temperature is 45°C, and the best cleaning temperature is 65°-80°C.
- Remove all traces of milk left over from the dipstick.
- Use suitable dairy detergent along with hot water to clean the tank.
- Rinse the tank thoroughly with plenty of fresh water for complete removal of detergent.

## 6.0 Very Important

- During cleaning, the milk agitator must be in the OFF position.
- Never mix an acid with an alkaline detergent, as this causes the formation of hazardous gases.
- The tank should be cleaned immediately after it has been emptied.
- Never wet electrical elements during cleaning.
- Never use a high-pressure water jet for cleaning the exterior/interior of the tank.

## 7.0 Safety Devices

Following are the protective and safety devices provided for the refrigeration system:

- MCB for the condensing unit.
- Glass fuse for the control circuit.

# HP/LP Cutouts

## 7.1 Overload for Compressor
The Control Panel stops the power supply to the compressor if the compressor takes more current than the preset value. Identify the reason for the overcurrent drawn and press the **RESET** button on the Control Panel.

## 7.2 High Pressure/Low Pressure Cutout (HP/LP)
The device stops the electric supply to the compressor if:
1. The discharge pressure exceeds the preset value (370 psig).
2. The suction pressure drops below the preset value (30 psig).

The device is of the manual reset type; a push button on it must be pressed for resetting.

## 7.3 Compressor Internal Overload Protector (IOLP)
The IOLP is current and heat sensitive and is mounted at the star point of the three windings of the motor of the compressor. If the compressor current alone exceeds the limit, or if the motor winding temperature alone exceeds the limit, or if the combination of current and motor winding temperature goes beyond the safe operating limits, the IOLP trips.

After the IOLP trips, the windings are open, and no resistance is recorded by the Resistance Bridge/Multi Meter. It may take as long as 45-60 minutes for the IOLP to reset. Allow enough time for resetting.

## 7.4 Compressor Internal Pressure Relief Valve (IPRV)
The IPRV is mounted inside the compressor and on the discharge side. If the discharge pressure exceeds safe limits, the IPRV opens and delivers the hot discharge gas into the shell (suction side). This hot gas increases the ambient temperature around the IPRV, causing it to trip.

IPRV opening is characterized by a whistling sound from inside the compressor and excessive heating of the compressor shell.

**Important Note:** Never bypass any of the safety devices provided. Find and rectify the cause of tripping instead.

# Maintenance Guidelines for Air-Cooled Condenser

## 8.1 CONDENSER & FILTER CLEANING

The air-cooled condenser must be cleaned at regular intervals to prevent dust particles from clogging the air passages. The frequency of cleaning depends on the level of dust present at the location.

### Cleaning Instructions:
- **Air Blowers**: For cleaning the condenser, air blowers are useful.
- **Cleaning Agents**:
- **Caution**: Do not use acids or harsh cleaning agents for condenser cleaning.
- **Brush Usage**:
- If a brush is to be used, ensure that it is soft and applied gently over the fins.

### Important Notes:
- **Lubricating Oil**: Never charge the lubricating oil to the compressor at any time, as doing so will permanently damage the system.
- **Oil Traces**: Check for oil traces at regular intervals on the compressor valves. If oil traces are found at the valves of the compressor, tighten the nuts of the valves. Valves and nuts may loosen after some days or weeks of operation due to the continuous vibration of the compressor.

### Maintenance Checklist:
1. Tighten all electrical terminals.
2. Check insulation on the coolant line.

# Troubleshooting Guide for HVAC System Faults

## 1. Defective LP Switch
- **Action**: Check continuity both during ON & OFF position.
- **Recommendation**: Replace if required.

----

## 2. HP Fault
- **Condition**: If the discharge pressure of the compressor goes above preset value of 350 psi, an alarm with indication will be displayed in the panel.

### Possible Causes and Solutions:
| Cause                                   | Inspection Method                     | Solution                                      |
|-----------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Obstructed air flow from condenser      | Visual Inspection                     | Open window in front of condenser / clear any obstruction in front of condenser and ensure hot air is expelled out of the room. |
| High Ambient Temperature                | Visual Inspection                     | Try to avoid running of unit during peak temperature. Provide Air Cooler. |
| Condenser Fan not working / Low RPM     | Visual Inspection                     | Check Power Supply to Fan. Check Capacitor - replace if faulty. |
| Condenser Fins clogged                  | Visual Inspection                     | Clean with high pressure air and soft nylon brush by combing along the row of the fins. |
| Air/moisture entered into the system    | Check colour indicator in the sight glass | Purge air from the system once or twice, check the colour if not satisfied replace the refrigerant. |
| Solenoid Valve in closed position       | Check whether Valve opens with the start of the Compressor | Check Power supply and Solenoid Valve Coil, replace if coil burnt. |
| Wrong setting of HP Sense in the Panel  | Check by scroll key                  | Set HP FAULT ENABLE “OPEN-FAULT”. |
| Defective HP Switch                     | Check continuity both during ON & OFF position | Replace if required. |

**Note**: In case of HP Fault, push the RESET button provided on the HP Switch. After that, push the Reset button on the Panel and hold for 5-10 seconds until the alarm indication goes OFF on the Panel Board.

----

## 3. OL/UL Fault
- **Condition**: When current drawn by the CU goes above the preset value, an alarm with indication will be displayed in the panel.

### Possible Causes and Solutions:
| Cause                                   | Inspection Method                     | Solution                                      |
|-----------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Supply Voltage is Low                   | Check Voltage at Control Panel terminal | Ensure proper Power supply. |
| Weak/Faulty Running Capacitor           | Check the Running Capacitor with Multi Meter | Replace if faulty/week. |

----

This guide provides a structured approach to troubleshooting common faults in HVAC systems, ensuring that technicians can efficiently identify and resolve issues.

# Troubleshooting Guide for Compressor and Pump Systems

## High Ambient Temperature
- **Issue**: Compressor will run for a few minutes and stop.
- **Cause**: High ambient temperature causing a rise in discharge pressure.
- **Solution**: Ensure adequate ventilation so that hot air from the condenser expels out of the room and the condenser breathes fresh air.

## Electrical Issues
### OL/UL Fault
- **Description**: No supply to Control Panel when current drawn by the Compressor Unit (CU) goes below the preset value.
- **Alarm**: An alarm with indication will be displayed in the panel.
- **Action**:
- Check supply from the source.
- Ensure proper power supply; phase and neutral connection is terminal sensitive.

### OV/UV Fault
- **Description**: Supply voltage at Control Panel terminal is higher/lower than the preset value (180–260V).
- **Alarm**: An alarm with indication will be displayed in the panel.
- **Action**:
- Check power supply from the main source to Control Panel terminal.
- Check set points in the control panel.
- If MCB is OFF, perform a visual inspection and put the MCB ON.

## Pump Trip
- **Description**: Pump taking high current than the preset value.
- **Alarm**: Pump stops working and an alarm with indication will display in the Control Panel.
- **Action**:
- Check voltage & current and reset if required.
- If the compressor does not start after five attempts, the pump trips. Press the reset button for 10-20 seconds.

## Low Battery
- **Description**: DC battery not charged or drained fully.
- **Alarm**: When the voltage in the DC battery goes below the preset value, an alarm with indication will be displayed in the DC Panel.
- **Action**:
- Check voltage with a multimeter.
- Recharge the battery at a charging shop and reconnect.
- Check the battery charger in the inverter which supplies 24V to the battery.
- Check & tighten lugs in the battery terminals.
- Replace the battery if necessary.

----

### Visual Inspection Checklist
- Ensure proper connection at all supply terminals for the compressor.
- Check continuity at the terminal of the compressor.
- Inspect the voltage and current levels regularly.

### Important Notes
- Always ensure adequate ventilation in the compressor room.
- Regularly check the battery status and connections to avoid low battery alarms.
- Maintain proper voltage levels to prevent OV/UV faults.

### Conclusion
This guide provides a structured approach to troubleshooting common issues related to compressor and pump systems. Regular maintenance and checks can prevent many of these issues from occurring.

# Maintenance Checklist for Dairy Equipment

## 1. Compressor Issues

### 1.1 No Supply to Compressor
- **Inspection Type:** Visual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Check complete power supply circuit, MCB, and contactor (In-Contactor Out).

### 1.2 Start/Run Capacitor/Potential Relay Faulty
- **Inspection Type:** Visual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Check Capacitor, Potential Relay & run Capacitor.

### 1.3 Compressor Faulty
- **Action Required:**
- Check continuity at Compressors Terminal & Body earth.
- Replace Compressor.
- Replace Filter Drier each time compressor is replaced.

----

## 2. Milk Chilling Issues

### 2.1 Milk Not Getting Chilled
- **Cause:** Discharge pump flow rate low
- **Action Required:**
- Check Flow rate (should be 10-12 lpm).
- Ensure Valves are fully open.
- No air trapped in the flow line & pump.

### 2.2 DC Battery Voltage Low
- **Action Required:** Check battery voltage as it may reduce RPM of Pump.

### 2.3 Length of Black Hose Pipe
- **Action Required:** Ensure the length is appropriate; excessive length may affect performance.

### 2.4 Leakage in Fittings
- **Action Required:** Inspect for and repair any leaks.

### 2.5 Milk Storage Tank Sensors Showing Faulty Readings
- **Action Required:** Cross-check with manual readings and replace the thermocouple if necessary.

### 2.6 Agitator Not Working
- **Inspection Type:** Visual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Check Agitator functioning.

### 2.7 Less Quantity of Milk in Active Storage Tank
- **Action Required:** Ensure minimum quantity of milk (at least 150-200 liters) is present in the tank corresponding to the position of the sensor.

----

## 3. Agitator Issues

### 3.1 Not Working
- **Cause:** No supply to the agitator
- **Inspection Type:** Manual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Check complete power supply circuit from Panel Board terminal to Agitator and check corresponding Glass Fuse.

### 3.2 Faulty Capacitor
- **Inspection Type:** Manual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Replace the capacitor.

### 3.3 Obstruction in Movement of the Shaft
- **Inspection Type:** Visual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Rotate shaft by hand to check whether it rotates freely; remove any obstruction.

### 3.4 Damaged Bearings
- **Inspection Type:** Visual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Rotate shaft by hand to check whether it rotates freely; replace the bearings if necessary.

### 3.5 Damaged Gear Mechanism
- **Inspection Type:** Visual Inspection
- **Action Required:** Rotate shaft by hand to check whether it rotates freely; replace broken gear/gearbox as required.

----

This structured checklist provides a comprehensive guide for troubleshooting common issues with dairy equipment, ensuring that all necessary inspections and actions are clearly outlined for effective maintenance.

# Promethean Spenta Technology Conventional Milk Cooling System

## Troubleshooting Note
The above troubleshooting guidelines are only for addressing the problems. In case of any difficulties, contact a Promethean Service Engineer. Do not allow any unskilled technician to handle the problem, as they may damage the system.

----

## 10.0 DO’S

### General
- Install the tank in a wide, ventilated room with proper water supply and drainage.
- Ensure perfect leveling of the tank by authorized personnel.
- Clean the tank only with soft brushes and sponges suitable for stainless steel.
- Ensure the inner tank is clean before taking the milk inside the tank.

### Refrigeration
- Ensure proper ventilation around the condensing unit.
- Keep the condenser free from dust and dirt; it can be cleaned by means of a brush or can be blown with compressed air.
- Ensure the condenser fins are not bent.

### Electrical
- Ensure proper earthing.
- Ensure proper supply voltage & phase sequence.

----

## 11.0 DON’TS

### General
- Do not enter the tank wearing either shoes or slippers.
- Do not damage the surface by using files, steel wool, sandpaper, or similar abrasive materials.

### Refrigeration
- Do not switch on the condensing unit when TSS is empty.
- Do not use any other refrigeration than the recommended one.
- Do not use wire mesh to clean the condenser.
- Do not charge refrigerant or oil to the compressor.
- Do not topple the machine; the compressor is hanging on the spring inside the shell.
- Do not puncture the condenser coil as the system is under pressure.

### Electrical
- Do not service the equipment unless the mains supply is cut off.
- Do not splash water on the control panel and do not bypass any safety and protective devices. Find out the faulty component and rectify/replace it immediately.

----
